awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Colonial Encounters of Sami Reindeer Herders in Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation research investigates the role of Sami reindeer herders in Alaska, asking how relations among Sami, Alaska Natives, and government officials shaped the American colonial history of the territory. Sami residents in Norway were recruited in the late 1800s to instruct Alaska Natives in the practice of reindeer herding. This experiment in pastoralism introduced a new subsistence economy to Alaska, transforming Indigenous communities and human relations with animals. This research will investigate the role of Sami in the development of herding in Alaska, highlighting the concept of diasporic indigeneity; that is, how Sami experienced indigeneity in the homelands of other Indigenous peoples. Research will also contribute to the comparative study of reindeer herding, a critical subsistence activity in many Arctic communities.

This project employs textual analysis and photo elicitation in conjunction with semi-structured interviews to better understand the Sami experience in Alaska and the colonial context in which Sami lived and worked. The work will explore government documents reporting on the reindeer program in Alaska, personal letters and accounts, and photos from archives in the United States. The resulting dissertation and community presentations in Norway and the U.S. will enhance understanding of linked Alaska Native and Indigenous European histories and facilitate the visual repatriation of photographs to Sami communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This doctoral dissertation project focused on the recruitment of Northern Sámi reindeer herders from Norway to Alaska by the United States government. This process started in 1894 and opened a new transnational space between Fennoscandia and North America. Sámi are known for their deep Indigenous knowledge of reindeer herding. They were hired to pass on their art to Alaska Native apprentices and facilitate reindeer herding in Alaska at the turn of the 20th century. Their involvement, which lasted until 1937, had lasting effects in Sápmi (homeland of the Sámi) and North America. This can be seen for example in art, visual culture, and the steady interest in Alaskan Sámi ethnohistory. However, the contributions made by Sámi reindeer herders and their families in Alaska were not well understood.

To shed new light on the role played by Sámi in Alaska, Lotvonen used a multi-method approach. She analyzed archival sources and photographic collections from North America and Sápmi, examined oral histories, and carried out ethnographic and photo-elicitation fieldwork in Norwegian Sápmi (Guovdageaidnu/Kautokeino). Through these methods, Lotvonen offers a detailed account of the Sámi participation in the Alaska Reindeer Service as captured in government reports and in the words and memories of Sámi herders themselves (and their descendants). The use of archival photographs as a tool for photo elicitation has been important for documenting Sámi perspectives.

Focusing on Sámi point of views revealed a relational world in which ecological, cultural, and political forces overlap. Lotvonen's analysis of bureaucratic texts highlights changing views of reindeer herding within the Reindeer Service, and the role government agents played in eroding the influence of Sámi herders in Alaska. In contrast, oral history sources tell a story of resiliency and adaptation. During their time in Alaska, Sámi families built close relations with Alaska Native communities. In the end, however, new legislation passed in 1937 made it impossible for Sámi herders to keep doing what they did best—caring for reindeer. Some of them moved out of Alaska, while others stayed and found new ways of making a living.

Through collaboration with various Sámi institutions as well as knowledge bearers in Guovdageaidnu (Norway), Lotvonen's dissertation ends with an investigation of the transnational connections built among descendant communities in North America and Sápmi. Her findings contribute to anthropological discussions of circumpolar reindeer herding (past and present), Sámi ethnohistory, multicultural encounters, as well as to ongoing conversations regarding northern Indigenous diasporas.

This project culminated with Lotvonen's doctoral dissertation, entitled "Ballad of the Laablaaqs: The Relational Worlds of Sámi Reindeer Herders in Alaska" (2024). Knowledge and insights gained through the research process was shared through community presentations in Norway (Guovdageaidnu) and the United States (Sámi Center for North America), social media outreach, and a booklet entitled Across the North: Alaskan Sámi Visual History in Archival Photographs. The booklet is of value to the communities served (groups of people interested in this history, Alaskan Sámi descendants, cultural organizations, archives, etc.).
